column19: Money has been allocated to cover immediate expenses related to the epidemic, and the Government has stated that additional fiscal support measures will be implemented as the situation develops. As of the 5th of April, there is no further information regarding these additional measures.
column64: On March 28 the Capital, Kabul, went into lockdown where residents were unable to leave their house without a valid  reason. All restaurants, hotels, sauna, cafes, public bathing centers, shrines, gyms, parks and other stores will were closed, with the exceptions of grocery stores and banks. The lockdown was initially planned for 3 weeks, but has been extended. Other cities and provinces are in varying degrees of lockdown, but most have required all but non essential businesses to close.

column19: As of the 3rd of April, no fiscal or monetary measures have been reported
column64: Although Angola is in a State of Emergency, they are allowing non-essential commercial and industry activities to operate - in addition to some public services.

column19: Reduction in the policy rate from 1.0% to 0.5%; reduction in the interest rate for the overnight lending facility from 1.9% to 0.9%; maintain the interest rate for the overnight deposit facility unchanged, at 0.1%
The Federal Government has reduced a number fees for the private sector, cut costs for essential utilities, and liquidity support for SMEs.

Measures have been aimed at encouraging bank lending through (i) lower reserve requirements on bank lending to households and SMEs; (ii) regulations that limit banks’ holdings of central bank paper to provide space for SME lending; and (iii) temporary easing of bank provisioning needs and of bank loan classification rules (i.e. extra 60 days to be classified as non-performing)

The Central Bank of Armenia reduced the policy rate by 25 bps to 5.25 percent on March 17. The interbank market has been active, and the central bank has easily met liquidity needs so far and provided a few FX swap operations to assure sufficient liquidity in dram and in FX.
NA

Economic stimulus package that will support business investment, provide cashflow assistance to support SMEs & their employees, household stimulus payments & targeted support for most affected regions
Liquidity support & job security hardship fund for SMEs and family businesses. Provisions on deferrals for VAT.
Left the refinancing rate unchanged at 7¼ percent, but raised the floor of the interest rate corridor (within a de facto floor system) by 125 bps to 6¾ percent
As of the 3rd of April, no fiscal or monetary measures have been reported
column64: There has only been limited attempts to control the spread the virus. Borders have remained open, although there are restrictions for people entering from at risk counties. Citizens have been instructed to watch their hands regularly.

column19: Corporate, income, and VAT payment deadlines extended for two months

Benin has spent US$ 17 million on mitigation and prevention strategies relating to covid. The central bank announced a number of additional measures: increasing liquidity, refinancing bank loans for private companies, systems changes to support  refinancing. The costs and reach of these central bank measures are available as of the 3rd of April.
column64: The Government has taken a number of measures to slow the spread of the virus. Travel between cities has been restricted, and within cities restaurants have closed, bars and nightclubs are closed; gatherings of more than 10 people are banned; people are required to maintain distance of at least one meter (three feet) from one another; markets, shops, and other merchants are allowed to remain open, albeit with limited service.

column19: The Government announced that it will spend 41 billion CFA francs to be spend on health care and prevention. Under the Ministry of Economy, Finance and Development, a report on measures to mitigate the effects of covid on the national economy announced that there would be changes to finance laws and the upcoming budget to mitigate the impacts of Covid 19. As of the 4th of April, no additional information regarding these measures is available. The Central Bank of African States have announced a number of monetary measures - such as providing additional liquidity to banks, setting up frameworks within banks to support firms with repayments,
column64: The IMF reports thats that government has adopted several containment measures, including social distancing, a nationwide curfew, closure of schools and universities, cancelation of major public events, closure of terrestrial borders, suspension of commercial flights, and quarantine of the affected cities.

column19: As of the 4th of April the Ministry of Finance is revising the budget, and has allocated additional funding for health services. The Bangladesh Bank announced that it will buy treasury bonds and bills from Banks, and that it will undertake further actions to ensure that there is adequate liquidity within the nation's financial system. While there has been reports of an upcoming stimulus package from the Government for firms and workers, details regarding the amount and allocation have not been released by the Government.  The World Bank announced that it would fast track $100 million USD to support Bangladesh in responding to COVID 19.
column64: The Government has ordered the closure of public and private offices, and while many factories have closed, there has not been a government directive.

column19: Business & employment support: increasing the capital of the state-run Bulgarian Development Bank to support businesses, paying 60% of the salaries of workers that companies would otherwise fire, delay payments of annual corporate tax until the end of June and offer interest-free loans to workers put on leave

The government has introduced a stimulus package with several economic measures - including: unemployment support, utility support, fee exemptions for tourism and other industries, doubling liquidity fund for SMEs.
The Government has introduced a range of support measures - including health care, food programs, income support for the unemployed as well as tax deferrals.

The government has created a health fund to cover the costs of covid patients and is also paying a minimum salary to workers that are in industries impacted by covid. The government is also facilitating funding for sme's.
NA

Reduce the statutory cash reserve requirements;Extend the time period to classify targeted non-performing loans in sectors such as restaurants, transportation and distribution companies, and other affected areas, from 3 months to 6 months;grace periods for servicing interest and/or principal components of commercial loans and ancillary loans, as needed and where commercially viable;Reduce risk-weights for banks on loans in the tourism sector from 100% to 50%;Review financial institutions’ business continuity and cybersecurity plans to ensure that an adequate level of financial services will be available to the public.

The IMF reports that the Government will provide families with: direct payments, food, and discounts on utilities (electricity, gas and water). The Government will also postpone payment of corporate taxes, and provide loans to companies to pay their employees. The Central Bank has also announced measures to increase liquidity, by purchasing bonds and pension funds, to the cost of 3.5 billion Bolivianos.

Congress declared a public calamity on the 20th of March, and introduced a range of measures to help mitigate economic impact of the virus. Including temporary income support, tax support and credit extensions. The central bank has reduced interest rates to historic lows.
NA

The government introduced a range of measures in March - mainly around tax, utility and social support to vulnerable households. However, as of August there is no confirmed total spend of these measures. The central bank has decreased rates to a historic low of 2.2%

The Royal Monetary Authority has established a economic stimulus package, effective on the 14th of April,  which includes loans and support for businesses engaged in the import and supply of essential goods; the tourism sector; and micro-loans to small businesses - with waivers on both loans and interest. The IMF reports that Nu 2 billion has been allocated to the ministry of health by the Government, which has also delayed Business Income Taxes and deferred sales tax and waived rent charges for business in tourism.

The President has announced a number of measures, including establishing a COVID-19 Relief Fund which the Government initially invested 2 Billion Pula, and has asked the private sector to continue to contribute to. On March 31st the President announced an upcoming fiscal stimulus package that would: support workers, stabilize business; supply necessary resources, explore opportunities to diversify the economy, However, as of April 4 there is no information regarding the distribution
column64:
The Government has adopted a number of restrictions, with May 22nd a tentative date for lifting them. As part of the restrictions citizens are required to stay at home, movement out of the
home is only restricted to those performing essential services and transporting essential goods. Those permitted to travel will be required to have a COVID-19 TRAVEL PERMIT issued by Government.

column19: The IMF has reported the Government will undertake health and prevention measures, which will cost an estimated 27 billion of FCFA. The Bank of Central African States has lowered interest rates, and will take actions to increase liquidity of banks.
column64: According to the IMF, the Government has taken a number of actions to slow the spread of the virus. Including a ban on gatherings of more than 15 people, closing schools and public establishments, and restricting movement between cities.

column19: Temporary income support for workers and parents, flexibility for taxpayers,credit support for businesses;Payment deferrals for individuals and businesses; audits suspended for four weeks.Three-month wage subsidy of 10 percent to small businesses

Short-time working compensation from the unemployment insurance fund. Companies will only have to bear the loss of one day's work independently before they are entitled to unemployment insurance support. VAT payment holidays for the rest of the year.
$11.75 billion stimulus package;Tax payment deferral for small businesses i.e tax payments for companies that have annual sales of less than $12 million.

Liquidity support by increasing funds for reverse repurchase operations; extensions on stock pledges and bond maturity dates of debt; hedging tools for A-share market; lowered bank reserve requirement.
VAT reduced from 3 percent to 1 percent for small businesses until the end of May; VAT cut on supplies related to the outbreak.CIT losses incurred in 2020 will be provided with a longer tax loss carry-forward period (i.e., 8 years, vs the standard 5 years). Full refund of carried forward excess input VAT balances may be granted to enterprises engaged in production of supplies for COVID-19 protection and containment.

On the 1st of April the Prime minister announced a solidarity fund of 650 billion FCFA for the economy, to support businesses and employment. Of which, 250 billion will be used support private businesses, 100 billion will support small and medium enterprises, 100 million will be used to help the informal sector. The remaining 250 million will be used for the nations main economic sectors, notably cashews, cotton and rubber.  to  Additional measures to support business include 3 months in which business taxes will be postponed for hotels and tourist reliant business, and that tax audits for all business will be postponed.
column64: The Government has taken a number of measures to limit the spread of the virus. Including, international travel restrictions, a night time curfew - between 9PM and 5AM, school and business closures. Places in which people gather, such as nightclubs, restaurants, bars and theatres, have been forced to close - although there is not an explicit work from home directive.

column19: Over the next 3 months COVID-19-related health spending is expected to reach CFAF 6.5 billion. Fees for Mobile Money Transfers on the MTN platform have been suspended were suspended on March 19. The Bank of Central African States has lowered interest rates, and will take actions to increase banks liquidity.
column64: The Government shut its borders on the 30th March, and implemented additional lockdown measures on April 10. These include requiring people to wear a mask in public and additional testing facilities. However, many economic activities have continued.

column19:
Cut its base interest rate to 7.5% from 9% in order to cushion the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

The bank also said in a statement that it was cutting mandatory reserve requirements and providing liquidity to banks.
column64: The Government declared a state of emergency on the 24th of March, banning all public gatherings and restricting travel. Restaurants have been closed, as well as religious and sporting facilities.

column19: NA
NA

On the 30th of March, the Government announced a 30% reduction in taxes and custom tariffs for essential items, such as food and medicine. The President also announced that from the 1st of April the central banks reserve ratio would be reduced to 5%, for a period of 5 months. On the 4th of April the President announced establishing several bipartisan committees to respond to covid, one of which will focus on financial and economic affairs.
column64: According to the IMF, the  Government has restricted gatherings to no more than 20 people and closed the borders and implemented a curfew from 8PM - 5PM in the main province. Currently, there are few restrictions on businesses with the president  explaining that the dominance of the informal economy makes it difficult to implement business restrictions.

column19: NA
NA
NA
NA

Lowered the two-week repo rate by 50 basis points to 1.75%. At the same time, it lowered the Lombard rate to 2.75% and the discount rate to 0.75%. The change in rates takes effect on Tuesday 17 March 2020. Tax deferrals options.

Reduced hours compensation benefits, tax related liquidity assistance to businesses (tax deferrals, enforcement measures such as penalties for late payments waved), expansion of existing liquidity programmes. 

Additional measures are to be decided upon by 27th March (Merkel’s cabinet has already approved, but parliament and Bundesrat need to approve as well). These measures will include: Direct subsidies up to 15K to small business owners/freelancers, no eviction of people not able to pay rent, stabilization of larger companies from a special fund (eventually government direct investment up to 100 billion Euro), loosening of bankruptcy rules. 

There is also direct support of 30 billion Euro to health system.

On the 31st of March the Government established the Emergency and Solidarity Fund COVID-19, with an initial  endowment of one billion Djibouti Francs, and encouraged additional contributions from local and international partners. The stated goal of the fund is both to to support the nation's health, but also to promote financial and economic stability. As of the 4th of April, there is no specific information as to how this will be distributed.
column64: The Government has limited business activity to only essential industries, such as health care and food provision - and restricted travel into and within the country.

column19: NA

If a company makes a notice saying that it has to either lay off 30 percent of their workers or fire at least 50 people, the state has agreed to take on 75 percent of workers’ salaries, up to $3,288 per month. (This would preserve the income for all employees earning up to $52,400 per year.). 
The state will guarantee 70 percent of new bank loans to companies. 
Compensation for companies for their fixed expenses, like rent and contract obligations, depending on their level of income loss.
30-day delay on VAT payments and four-month delay on labor contributions.
NA

Taxes for individuals and businesses have been postponed until April 20. The reserve bank have lowered the reserve requirement ratio from 10 percent to 8 percent. As of April 3, no additional monetary measures have been reported.
NA

The Government has announced a stimulus of EGP 100 billion in financial support, half of which will be used to aid the tourism sector. Pension payments have been increased by 14%, energy costs have been lowered, and there are tax reliefs for businesses in tourism and vulnerable industries. The Ministry of Social Solidarity has also announced a one of payment to informal workers, and increased payments to welfare recipients. The central bank has reduced credit and discount rates from 12.75% to 9.75%. Both business tax and personal tax deadlines have been extended, and administrative fees waived.
As of the 3rd of April, no fiscal or monetary measures have been reported
column64: The Government has declared a national emergency, with a lockdown imposed from the 21st of April. Most citizens are required to stay at home, although exceptions have been made for grocery stores and major productive and service sectors (manufacturing, food processing, construction, trucking).

column19: State-backed credit lines in form of burden-sharing scheme for banks to help companies limit c-19 impact; state will guarantee: 80% of unpaid loans to self-employed workers & SMEs, 70% of potential losses from new loans & 60% of renewed unpaid credit lines for upto 5yrs.Tax deferrals for six months.
Suspends the calculation of interests on their tax arrears for the period of emergency with retroactive effect as from 1 March to 1 May

The Prime Minister announced an aid package of US $154 million on the 23rd of March, but as of the 3rd of April, there is no information about how this funding will be divided and when it will be provided. The World Bank has approved funding from the International Development Association $82.6 million ($41.3 million grant and $41.3 million credit). The central bank has provided 15 billion birr (0.45 percent of GDP) of additional liquidity to private banks to facilitate debt restructuring and prevent bankruptcies.
column64: The Prime Minister declared a state of emergency on the 8th of April, and implemented more stringent measures, including banning gatherings of more than four people. This ban applies to all religious, governmental, non-governmental, commercial, political and social gatherings. Furthermore, commercial and private employers bound by the Labour proclamation will be prohibited from reducing their workforces or prematurely terminating employment contracts.

column19: Corporate tax payments delayed;liquidity to businesses as well as broader loan guarantee programs. EUR27m in extra spending on health care and EUR73m to stave off acute corporate funding pressures. State Pension Fund will buy EUR1bn of commercial paper.The government will increase capacity to guarantee loans to SMEs.Business Finland will provide emergency aid to companies in worst affected industries
NA

Liquidity plan for startups:short terms refinancing scheme, early payment of tax credits, accelerated payment of already-planned investments; guarantees over cash flow costs.Suspension of payments for some taxes; direct tax payments delayed for three months.The extension does not apply for value added tax (VAT), assimilated taxes or withholdings of employees’ individual income taxes by employers.
As of the 25th of April, there is no information regarding financial or monetary responses to covid.

The IMF has reported the governments projections are to spend 17 billion FCFA on Covid related activities, with FCFA 4 billion already placed in a fund to prevent the spread of the virus. As of the 4th of April, there is no information directly from the Government regarding these measures, how they may be directed and when they will come into effect. The Bank of Central African States has lowered interest rates, and will take actions to increase banks liquidity.
column64: The Government has responded by: bans on social gatherings, travel restrictions and a night time curfew. However, there has been minimal impact on economic activity.

column19:
Reductions in interest rates and expansion of lending: Bank of England rate reduced by 50 points to 0.25%, in addition to a reduction in the UK countercyclical capital buffer rate from 1% to 0% of banks’ exposures to UK borrowers with immediate effect to support lending to businesses. Additionally, under 'Term Funding scheme with additional incentives for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises' (TFSME), four-year funding being offered by Bank of England of at least 5% of participants’ stock of real economy lending at interest rates at, or very close to, Bank Rate.

Fiscal policy for job retention: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme: employers will be able to contact HMRC for a grant to cover most of the wages of people who are not working but are furloughed and kept on payroll, rather than being laid off. Government grants will cover 80% of the salary of retained workers up to a total of £2,500 a month. Available back dated from 1st March for at leat three months. 

Loans/tax cuts/grants for businesses: new lending facility for low cost government backed loans for large businesses, in addition to a 'Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme' for SMEs - interest free government backed loans of up to £5 million available for 12 months. Next quarter of VAT payments deferred until end of June, and businesses will have until the end of the financial year to repay those bills. Abolished business ratesand additional cash grants fo £25,000 this year if in hospitality, retail and leisure sectors. Cash grants of £25,000 being provided for small businesses.

Social safety nets: Universal Credit standard allowance and Working Tax Credit basic element increased by £1,000 a year for the next 12 months. Minimum income floor for Universal Credit suspended so every self-employed person can now access Universal Credit at a rate equivalent to Statutory Sick Pay for employees. Local Housing Allowance will cover at least 30% of market rents to support renters. 3 momth mortgage holiday being offered by mortgage providers.
NA

Bank of Ghana cuts policy rate by 150 basis points. Reduced primary Reserve Requirement from 10 percent to 8 percent.Waiving Mobile money charges for transactions as well waived off fees on all electronic payments.
column64: The Government ordered a partial lockdown of urban areas on the 30th of March, and while this was intended to be lifted on the 23rd of April, as of the 6th of May it continues. The partial lockdown means the closure of schools and banning on public gatherings of more than 25 people - although businesses have not been forced to close. The Government is encouraging people to practice social distancing, wearing masks and washing their hands.

column19: The Government has taken several actions in response to covid. On the 31st of May, the Government released a plan to supply essential products to 36,000 homes at risk of vulnerability, with the emphasis on Annobon, Corisco and Elobey, however there are currently no details on costing. On the 3rd of April the Ministry of Mines announced it will take a number of measures to protect and support national employment in the oil sector, however the details and cost of these actions is yet to be released.
column64: The IMF reports that, government has restricted travel, shut down schools and banned large public gatherings. Public places (such as religious facilities and businesses) are allowed to remain open if they provide hand sanitiser.

column19: The IMF has reported that the Government has reallocated 500 million dalasi from the Health Budget to respond to COVID 19.  As of the 4th of April, there is no information directly from the Government regarding these measures, how they may be directed and when they will come into effect.  In February, the Central Bank reduced its monetary policy rate to 12%, and increased the standing deposit facility rate to 3%.
column64: A state of emergency was declared on March 27, leading to the closure of all non-essential public and private businesses, with was extended by an additional 45 days on  April 4. Public gatherings are limited to 10 people.

column19: As of the 3rd of April, no fiscal measures have been reported. On the 31st of March, the Bank of West African States announced it would: (1) Increase the resources made available to banks; (2) Broaden access to refinancing, with 1,700 private companies given access, who were not previously accepted in its portfolio; (3) allocate 25 billion to the subsidy fund of the West African Development Bank (BOAD); (4) make banks aware of the use of the resources available on the special window for refinancing credits granted to small and medium-sized enterprises; (5) set up, with the banking system, a suitable framework to support companies affected by the consequences of the pandemic and who are encountering difficulties in repaying the credits which have been granted to them.
column64: The IMF reports that schools and markets have been closed, but does not mention businesses closures.

column19: NA

VAT payments suspended for four months; social security contribution payments suspended until June 30;VAT reduced (from 24 percent to 6 percent) for goods related to addressing the outbreak..The suspension of the payment of non-overdue loan installments is provided for three (3) months. Wage support.The new measures provide that the Easter Bonus for 2020 will be fully paid to all employees by every business.
NA
NA
NA

The Government has announced a spending plan to support the healthcare system and vulnerable groups and businesses. The total plan is L3,800 mn (150 million USD). Approximately one third of the population will be given access to food and basic needs supplies. They have also deferred income taxes for small and medium sized business. The Central bank has decreased interest rates, and he government has mandated that all supervised financial institutions must support individuals affected by the crisis.

Support to domestic economy through: deferral of payment of income and profit tax, social, health and pension contributions by three months, with an option to be postponed by a further three months; minimum wage financing for 71,000 workers

The IMF reports that Government spending will increase by approximately 1.6% of total GDP. Additional funding will be allocated to healthcare, food and cash transfers. Cash transfers will be targeted at worker and households impacted by social distancing measures, such as teachers. The central bank has taken several measures for the next three months. Specifically, reducing refinance rates, lowering repaymentment obligations and suspending fees in the interbank payment system.

Employers temporarily not required to pay social security taxes.Delay of social security contributions for Hospitality and tourism; Entertainment, film industry, performing art; Sport services; Event organization; Gambling. Around 80,000 SMEs (mainly in the services sector) will be exempt from the small business tax (the payment of the tax by other companies in affected sectors will be deferred until the end of the state of emergency)

Special provisions for hotels and restaurants:tax for businesses in these sectors are suspended.Six-month delay for income tax payments; corporate and income tax on imports delayed. Manufacturing companies in Indonesia will not have to pay out income tax for their workers for six months. import tax exemptions (non-final withholding tax relief) for 19 manufacturing sectors and export-oriented companies from April 2020 to September 2020.

Long-term repo operations (LTRO) to reduce interest rates and boost lending; fine-tuning variable rate Repo auctions;to address any additional demand for liquidity and to provide flexibility to the banking system in year-end liquidity management
column64: On the 24th of March India introduced a national lockdown for 21 days, which has since been extended. As of the 7th of May, the lockdown is planned to be lifted by the 17th of May. With the exception of essential workers, such as healthcare workers and food providers, no one is allowed to leave their home. The Ministry of Home Affairs has stated that people could spend up to a year in jail for failing to abide by the stay at home order.

column19: €200 million liquidity support fund for impacted firms;Suspension of interest on late payments for VAT and “pay as you earn” (PAYE);€2.4 billion for income support. Increase in welfare benefits
Deferred payments for employee taxes; subsidy for vulnerable and poor
NA

Postponement of the payment deadline for part of the public levies on source;Postponement of the payment deadline for part of the social security tax;No penalty or surcharge on account of the late payments.

Reduction of costs for business and special assistance to the self-employed.Provision of access to credit for businesses.Tax payment delays.Expansion of social security nets.Relief of immediate economic burdens on citizens
Tax payment delays for personal, business and VAT. Along with tax credit provisions for sanitation and retail services
The Minister of Finance introduced tax cuts, equivalent to 0.5% of GDP. The Government has also made temporary cash transfers to businesses and households impacted by lockdown measures.

The Ministry of finance has introduced a range of measures: sales exemptions on sanitizers and medical equipment; assistance to the elderly; price ceilings on essential items; and postponement of duty collections.

Liquidity support for financial markets and companies through purchases of stocks, bonds, assets at zero interest; one-year loans to companies running short of cash. Delays in income, consumption, and gift tax deadlines.

The IMF estimates that the additional spending will be US$9.4 million, for health and other social spending. The Government has also extended deadlines for personal and business taxes. The world bank has financed a grant of US$ 6 million to support with the health and social consequences of the crisis. The National Bank has delay

The central bank (1) lowered its policy rate by 100 bps to 7.25 percent; (2) lowered banks’ cash reserve ratio by 100 bps to 4.25 percent; (3) increased the maximum tenor of repurchase agreements from 28 to 91 days; and (4) announced flexibility to banks regarding loan classification and provisioning for loans that were performing on March 2, 2020, but were restructured due to the pandemic;waiving or reducing of charges on mobile money transactions to disincentivize the use of cash.
column64: The Government has implemented a curfew, from 7PM to 5AM, banned large gatherings, and suspended international flights.

column19: NA

The IMF has reported additional fiscal spending in the health care sector, of approximately 70 million USD. The Government has also announced tax concessions and credit support to businesses, and low-interest loans to banks. Income support will be provided for Government workers who are laid off as a result of the virus, but there is no current plan for more general wage support. The National Bank of Cambodia has also undertaken measures to increase liquidity, such as lowering interest rates. The IMF also reports that the Government has suspended exporting white rice, to ensure that there sufficient local supply.
As of the 25th of April, there is no information regarding financial or monetary responses to covid.
NA

On March 17 a supplementary budget of 10.9 trillion was passed. To be spent on: disease prevention and treatment; Loans and guarantees for businesses affected; Support for households affected; Support for local economies affected.  The IMF reports that additional measures have been announced, but as of the 25th of April have not been passed as legislation. These additional measures are a combined 19 trillion, for consumption coupons for low income households, tax exemptions, wage subsidies and tax benefits. Both the Government and the Bank of Korea has taken a number if measures to increase liquidity in the financial system. On March 24 the Government announced a stabilization plan of 100 trillion. This plan expanded lending and lending guarantees, purchased corporate and financial bonds, provided short term loans to companies in need. On the 22nd of April an addition 40 trillion was committed to expand the resources of the Korea development bank and provide assistance in key industries under strain, such as airlines and shipping.

The Government has allocated a several support measures including: postponing social security contributions; removing government fees on certain sectors; and providing loans and financing for businesses and banks.

The Government has established a committee to oversee COVID-19, and to seek extra funding. The IMF reports that 30 billion kip has been allocated by the Government, which is aso hoping to raise more from the fundraising campaign. The funds will primarily spent on health, but there are also tax exemptions for lower income earners and small businesses, and tax deferrals for companies impacted by the crisis (e.g., tourism). The reserve bank has announced that is will reduce its reserve requirement ratio
NA
As of the 3rd of April, no fiscal  or monetary measures have been reported. The World Bank has approved financing of US$1.5 million.
column64: On March 21st the Government issued a declaration enforcing social distancing, including limiting gatherings to 10 people and closing schools and churches. Banks and restaurants were allowed to continue operations, if people were separated by 5 feet. On the 10th of April the Government announced a state of emergency, and introduced more stringent guidelines - including the closure of al non-essential businesses.

column19: The IMF reported that the Government will implement a package of LD 500 million in covid related spending, however how this money will be spent has yet to specified. As of the 5th of April, there are no government documents outlining fiscal or monetary responses.
column64: Libya is also having an ongoing civil war, impacting the nations capacity to respond to the virus. The country’s borders have been closed, large public gatherings banned, and travel restrictions instituted, including between cities. On April 15, the Government of National Accord imposed a 24-hour curfew for a period of 10 days beginning on April 17

column19: NA
NA

Reduction in the Standing Deposit Facility Rate (SDFR) and the Standing Lending Facility Rate (SLFR) of the Central Bank by 25 basis points to 6.25 per cent and 7.25 per cent, respectively, with effect from 17 March 2020 and to reduce the Statutory Reserve Ratio (SRR) on all rupee deposit liabilities of licensed commercial banks (LCBs) by 1.00 percentage point to 4.00 per cent, with effect from the current reserve maintenance period

The IMF reports that the Governments has funded their current COVID response from the existing health care budget, and has been focused on  health care and prevention. The  Government has also called for private sector support, and Banking Sector in the country has contributed M2 million towards the National Response to Coronavirus (COVID-19). As of the 4th of April there are no fiscal policy measures. However, the Central Bank of Lesotho (CBL) announced it will (1) increase of the NIR target floor from US$630 million to US$660 million, and (ii) reduce the CBL rate by 100 basis points from 6.25 per cent to 5.25 per cent
per annum.
column64: The Government has adopted a number of measures, including school closures, travel bans, and closed non-essential retail.

column19: EUR 500 million for jobs and personal income protection;Tax payment delays and special provisions for select list of affected firms. Liquidity measures
Tax payment delays; tax cancellation available for successful application up to two months of tax.
Tax payment delays

The Government has announced a number of measures in response to COVID 19. On the 27th of March, the Government established the Special Fund for the Management of the Coronavirus Pandemic, with approximately 1 billion US. The EU and US have also contributed, and the Government has called for businesses and other actors to add to the fund. In addition to health services, financial support will be provided. Support will be given to citizens who lose their jobs, as well as suspending social security contributions for all citizens. The Ministry of Economy, Finance and Administration Reform announced there would be increased financing for SMEs, which will enable financing resources for companies whose cash flow has deteriorated due to COVID. This policy covers 95% of the amount of the loan and thus allows banks to quickly set up exceptional overdrafts to finance the working capital needs of the concerned enterprises. The interministerial Committee has been intensely monitoring the price of goods and services, particularly food, and has warned of sanctions against fraud and price speculation. On 17 March 2020, the Moroccan Central Bank decided to reduce interest rates by 25 basis points to 2%. As part of the nations state of emergencies, there has been an extension on all legal deadlines, including tax procedures.

The National Bank of Moldova has reduced the reserve ratio and interest rates to increase liquidity. The IMF has reported the country will adopt a comprehensive fiscal package, including supporting businesses and vulnerable households with social assistance and tax breaks. However, as of the 26th of April, there is no data regarding the total cost of this fiscal package.

The Government has established a new Operational Command Center to respond to covid, and coordinate healthcare services. The centre will also monitor goods and services, and strict measures have also been taken to control product prices and supplies.  On the 4th of April, legislation was passed to recognise COVID 19 as a state of emergency, and it is expected that this will lead to an increase in spending. On March 12, 2020, the World Bank provided a grant of $3.7 million to strengthen prevention against the COVID-19 pandemic, purchase materials and equipment, and train health workers.

The Government has announced a range of measures including: granting loan repayments; employment support; loans to family businesses; unemployment insurance - as well as increased social spending related to security and education.

On the 1st of April, the World Bank reported US$ 25.7 million in financing, through the Mali COVID 19 Emergency Response project. The objective of the project is to strengthen the capacity of the government of Mali to prevent, prepare for and respond to COVID-19 pandemic in Mali. . The project has 3 components: (1) Emergency COVID-19 Preparedness and Response, (2) Increasing Access to Health Care Services, (3) Implementation Management, Monitoring and Evaluation, and Coordination.  On the 31st of March, the Bank of West African States announced it would: (1) Increase the resources made available to banks; (2) Broaden access to refinancing, with 1,700 private companies given access, who were not previously accepted in its portfolio; (3) allocate 25 billion to the subsidy fund of the West African Development Bank (BOAD); (4) make banks aware of the use of the resources available on the special window for refinancing credits granted to small and medium-sized enterprises; (5) set up, with the banking system, a suitable framework to support companies affected by the consequences of the pandemic and who are encountering difficulties in repaying the credits which have been granted to them.
column64: The Government has taken a number of measures to respond to the virus, including suspending commercial flights, closing land borders, banning gatherings of more than 50 people, and closing schools, night clubs and bars.

Measures include income and commercial tax payments due in the second and third quarters of the fiscal year have been made extendable to end of the fiscal year, and an exemption for the 2 percent advance income tax on exports to the end of the fiscal year has been announced; and (iii) a COVID 19 Fund worth MMK 100 billion (US$70 million, 0.1 percent of GDP) has been established at the Myanmar Economic Bank to provide soft loans to affected business (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at a 1 percent per annum interest rate for a one-year period
column64: The Government has introduced a number of measures, including travel restrictions and bans on mass public gatherings. There is currently no national stay at home requirements, although restrictions vary by city. WIth restaurants in Yangon have been instructed to close except for delivery service. Additional movement restrictions have been introduced in 10 Yangon townships: South Okkalapa, Pabedan, Bahan, Mayangone, Insein, Shwe Pyi Thar, Hlaing Tharyar, Mingaladon, Tamwe, and Botahtaung. All residents must stay at home but can leave the house for work. When outside the home residents must wear a mask at all times and carry ID.

column19: NA

The Government has committed to an extra MNT 17 billion for health care spending, in addition to tax exemptions and unemployment benefits for low income families. The Central Bank of Mongolia lowered the policy rate on the 13th of April, from 9% to 8%.

To ease liquidity conditions, the central bank reduced reserve requirements by 150 basis points for both foreign currency and domestic currency deposits (to 11.5 percent and 34.5 percent respectively) on March 16. On March 22, it announced measures to support financial markets and encourage prudent loan restructuring by: (i) introducing a foreign currency credit line for institutions participating in the Interbank Foreign Exchange Market, in the amount of US$ 500 million, for a period of nine months; and (ii) waiving the constitution of additional provisions by credit institutions and financial companies in cases of renegotiations of the terms and conditions of the loans, before their maturity, for clients affected by the pandemic, until December 31
column64: In March the Government introduced measures to slow the spread of the virus, including banning gatherings of more than 50 people and school closures. On the 30th of March these measures were increased, to include closure of non-essential shops or, where applicable, their reduction in activity - as well as directing the industrial sector toward the production of goods necessary for the prevention and mitigation of the Covid-19 pandemic.

column19: The Government has created an emergency fund to aid in the crisis. The fund will be used to support the healthcare system, provide subsidies to low income households and financial support to businesses. Central bank has announced a number of measures to increase liquidity and banks resources, such as a drop in key rates (from 6.5% to 5%) and a drop in the loan facility rate (from 9% to 6.5%) and a drop in the reserve ratio (from 7% 5%).

Government of Mauritius announced the Wage Assistance Scheme to ensure that all employees in the private sector are duly paid their salary for the month of March 2020. The scheme concerns both Mauritians and foreign employees working in Mauritius. Waiver of penalty and interest fee on late tax payments

As of the 3rd of April, The UN Malawi reported that the Covid preparedness and response plan is budgeted at US$ 130.2 million, and that this will primarily be spent on healthcare. On the 1st of April, the Reserve Bank of Malawi’s Monetary Policy Committee cut the liquidity reserve requirement on domestic deposits from 5% to 3.75%, which will release primary liquidity across the banking system.
column64: The Government has developed a preparedness and Response Plan, requiring essential services continuing to function and critical businesses working in shifts. On the 14th of April the resident Mutharika announced a 21-day lockdown, however this was blocked by a high court temporary injunction on the 18th of April.

column19: Reduced its statutory reserve ratio by 100 basis points to 2.00%Exemptions from sales tax, services tax, and import duties.Allocation for travel vouchers, grants and tourism promotion.Stimulus package.Import duty and/or sales tax exemption will be granted on the import or domestic purchase of machinery and equipment to be used in port operations. Support for SMEs. The value-added activities conducted within the LMW and FIZ will be expanded to include supply-chain management, strategic procurement operation and total support solutions.

column64: The government declared a national state of emergency and adopted containment measures, including social distancing, work from home initiatives (including suspension of the parliament for 21 days), lockdowns in some regions, and travel bans on visitors from high-risk countries, and screening at ports of entry. On the 4th of May travel restrictions were relaxed, to allow travel within the country, but not to allow international travel.

column19: the BCEAO (the regional central bank) announced the following monetary and macro-financial measures with the aim of mitigating the negative economic impact of the Covid-19 crisis by: (i) providing CFAF 340 billion additional liquidity to bring the total liquidity made available to banks by weekly and monthly auctions to CFAF 4,750 billion; (ii) extending the collateral framework to access the BCEAO’s refinancing to include CFAF 1,050 billion of bank loans to prequalified 1,700 private companies that could thus benefit from better financing conditions, and (iii) setting-up a framework with the banking system to support firms with repayment difficulties. Other policy announcements included: (i) allocating FCFA 25 billion to the trust fund of the West African Development Bank (BOAD) to increase the amount of concessional loans to eligible countries to finance urgent investment and equipment expenses; (ii) communicating on the special program for refinancing bank credits granted to SMEs; (iii) initiating negotiations with firms issuing electronic money to encourage its usage; and (iv) ensuring adequate provision of banknotes for satisfactory ATM operation.
column64: The  country's largest outbreak has been in the capital, and much of the country's lockdown efforts aim to prevent the spread of the virus from the capital to other regions - through travel restrictions and quarantines. President declared a state of emergency on the 27th of March, and issued a curfew to shorten work hours and ban large gatherings.

column19: Interest rate reduction.Creation of special credit facility for SMEs. Regulatory forbearance
column64: There are variations in the measures different cities and states are implementing to prevent the spread of the virus. A “lockdown” was declared in Lagos, Abuja and Ogun states. Work at home is also encouraged in several states and government institutions while isolation centers are being expanded in Lagos state. Nationally, international airports, public and private schools, universities, stores and markets, have been closed - and public gatherings suspended.

column19: The IMF reports that the Government will strengthen social services and provide food packages to households in need.

Reduction in the policy rate by 0.75 percentage point to 0.25 percent.Overnight lending rate: 1.25 %.Reserve rate: -0.75 %. Through the Corona Virus Control and Relief Fund, Nepal has committed to increasing health spending and and social assistance - by subsidizing cost of essentials (such as utilities and food) and providing partial compensation for wages for those in the formal sector who have lost their job. The Nepal Rasta Bank has lowered taken measures to increase liquidity, lowering the cash reserve ratio from 4% to 3% and relaxed requirements on banks and financial institutions.

column19: The government has increased healthcare and social spending,  a utility subsidy and a suspension of payments for public services (e.g., electricity, landline phones). They have also extended tax relief and suspension of payments.

The Government introduced support for vulnerable households and extended tax repayments for SMEs. Households can also access subsidies for utilities. The central bank has cut the policy rate, bringing it to 0.25%.

The Government has announced a  P27.1-billion package to support the health sector and economy.  P3.1 billion will be spent on healthcare and prevention, the remainder will be used to: provide income support to vulnerable workers, support tourism and agriculture and support the development of technical skills - but supporting displaced workers upskilling and reskilling through education support. The Central bank has lowered interest rates and reserve requirements to increase liquidity.

column64: The Government has taken a number of measures to slow the virus, but not forced the closure of businesses. Many businesses are allowed to remain open, but must adhere to social distancing. There are explicit restrictions on certain types of businesses to promote social distancing, for example makres can open for non-essential items - but must only have 50% of vendors; and restaurants can open during the day, but must close by 7PM.

column19: The covid response package includes suspending tax payers, fees, and budgetary allocations to health care. The Central Bank has decreased interest rates twice since March.

column64: The Government has implemented a number of containment measures, including shutting down international borders, closing schools, and implemented a curfew.

column19: The Government has established the Response and Solidarity Fund fund, with contribution from the private sector and other agencies, for  FCFA 1000 billion. Half of the fund will be allocated to obtaining food. As of the 5th of April, the remainder of the fund has not been allocated, although the President noted that it will be used to support those sectors most impacted - in particular tourism and transport. In addition, there will be a reduction in tax debt, for a total amount of 200 billion. On the 31st of March, the Bank of West African States announced it would: (1) Increase the resources made available to banks; (2) Broaden access to refinancing, with 1,700 private companies given access, who were not previously accepted in its portfolio; (3) allocate 25 billion to the subsidy fund of the West African Development Bank (BOAD); (4) make banks aware of the use of the resources available on the special window for refinancing credits granted to small and medium-sized enterprises; (5) set up, with the banking system, a suitable framework to support companies affected by the consequences of the pandemic and who are encountering difficulties in repaying the credits which have been granted to them.
column64: The Government declared a national state of emergency on the 7th of May, and implemented a range of containment measures. Including travel bans, school closures, a curfew, and restrictions on public gatherings. However, there is not reports of forced business closures.

column19: Support targeted at the Tourism Sector : license fee waiver for hotels, travel agents and tourist guides. Defray costs related to COVID sanitization. Enhanced training and wage support in addtion to loans and property tax rebates. Other recent measures: a tripling of cash payouts to households, enhancement of financing schemes and setting aside loan capital of S$20 billion, and additional support to the most affected sectors.

The IMF reports that there is a stimulus package being debated by cabinet, with measures likely to include financial support in addition to health sector funding. The Government has reported receiving from China and other nations, as well as development partners such as the World Bank and IMF.

Lower monetary policy rate, special credit facility to finance the production and distribution of essential goods. Support to the private sector importing essential goods. Liquidity support to the banking sector
column64: The Government declared a national state of emergency on the 24th of March, for a period of 12 months. The countries borders have been closed, with flights suspended for three months and land borders restricted. Schools and Universities have been shut down, and public gatherings restricted to 100 people. While businesses have not been forced to shut, there is a national curfew (from 9PM to 7AM) in which everyone must be home and businesses not operating.

column19: The President has announced a fiscal package to support households and businesses, although as of the 24th of April, this plan has not been approved by the legislative Assembly. The support would total US$1 billion, which would provide loans and credits to businesses, food for households, wage support for companies that have had to close and an extension on income tax.

column64: According to the IMF, the Chadian Government has restricted gatherings to no more than 50 people and closed the borders and implemented a curfew from 8PM - 5PM in the main province. Currently, there are few restrictions on businesses.

column19: The IMF has reported that Togo has established a covid response plan, with a total estimated cost of CFAF 70 billion. However, the Government is reliant on outsider funding, and as of the 5th of April has only commit to 2 billion self funding. Income withholding tax cut from 3 percent to 1.5 percent for six months; doubled tax benefit for investing in long-term mutual funds.Reduction of withholding
tax rate.Acceleration of VAT refunds for domestic business operators including other tax provisions. Financial support for businesses includes soft loans at 2 per cent interest rates, debt moratorium and delayed debt repayments, and lower utilities expenses and other costs. Cash transfer to vulnerable groups.

On the 16th of April the president announced they would undertake a number of measures to support the economy, but did not specify the total cost of these measures. Measures include tax breaks for small and medium sized firms, support for workers and measures to support the production of essential goods. Support for the agriculture industry was highlighted as critical, and the Ministry of Agriculture has announced support for increasing crop rates by 40%. The IMF has also reported that authorities have requested disbursement under IMF Rapid Credit Facility instrument, and that they are also in discussion with other development partners - such as the World Bank. The IMF also reported that there had been headline inflation of 9.2%, and that the National Bank had lowered reserve requirements for local currency and allowed a one-off 5% depreciation to adjust the official exchange rate with cash market rate.

On the 20th of April the Government announced a number of fiscal measures in response to covid, including: a universal cash transfer system that will provide a monthly basic income to over 214,000 households, wage subsidies, waivers of electricity bills, and support for food.  The total cost of these measures was not reported.

The fiscan package includes: salary relief for people who are temporarily unemployed; Tax refunds for individuals and SMEs; Credit support for businesses.

On the 21st of March the Government announced a 2.5 billion TND emergency plan. Half of this money will fund public hospitals. The remainder will support those in temporary unemployment and cash transfers to low income  or vulnerable households - such as the elderly. Healthcare insurance will be maintained for all workers. Businesses and companies in the formal sector are able to waive their contributions to employees social security.

BoU’s commitment to provide liquidity assistance for a period of up to one year to financial institutions; (ii) ensuring that contingency plans of the supervised financial institutions guarantee the safety of customers and staff; (iii) mechanisms to minimise the likelihood of sound business going into insolvency due to lack of credit; (iv) waiving limitations on restructuring of credit facilities at financial institutions that may be at risk of going into distress. The government has reduced and delayed taxes - including a moratorium on tax audits; extending the deadline of individual taxes; and reduced real estate taxes.

The Government has postponed certain tax and pension obligations, and relaxed rules for claiming unemployment support. The Government has provided support to businesses impacted by Covid-19 and lockdowns. The centeral bank has tempoarily reduced the reserve requirement.

US$8.3 billion Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act and US$104 billion Families First Coronavirus Response Act which together provide 0.5 percent GDP for health care, sick leave, small business loans, and international assistance. Agreement has been reached on a US$2 trillion (around 10% GDP) that is expected to pass Congress in the coming days. The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act provides for transfers to households, extended unemployment insurance, food assistance, incentives for firms to maintain employees on payroll, loans and grants for businesses, funding for hospitals and health care infrastructure, transfers to state and local governments, and deferral of payroll tax obligations. Federal student loan obligations have been suspended for 60 days and tax filing deadlines have been delayed.
The government expanded healthcare funding; increased access to social welfare; subsidised business; and financed infustracture projects to support employment.

column64: On the 1st of May South Africa moved from a Level 5 (the strictest) to Level 4 Lockdown. During Level 5, only essential businesses were able to operate. At Level 4, restaurants can open for delivery only, mines and factories can reopen - but are restricted with the number of employees they are permitted - and must maintain social distancing amongst workers. Citizens are able to leave their houses once a day, for exercise, but there is a curfew from 8PM to 5AM in which no one can leave.

column19: Bank of Zambia announced measures to stimulate the use of e-money and reduce the use of cash, such as waiving fees for transactions below a certain threshold; relaxing the limits on single and total daily transactions for individuals, small scale farmers, and enterprises, and removing of transaction limits for corporate wallets; reducing interbank payment processing fees.

On April 2nd the UN and Zimbabwe jointly launched a response plan requesting US$ 715 million from the international community. This funding will be used to support health services, but also to maintain food security. As of the 5th of April there is no further information regarding funds raised.
